author: svpino
full_text:
Here is the first open-source, enterprise-grade RAG system that you can run in your environment.

You don't have to send your data anywhere. You can keep everything secure and compliant. You can run the entire system in your private network using Kubernetes.

And you can plug any
note_tweet_text:
Here is the first open-source, enterprise-grade RAG system that you can run in your environment.

You don't have to send your data anywhere. You can keep everything secure and compliant. You can run the entire system in your private network using Kubernetes.

And you can plug any LLM you want to it.

The system is GroundX. This is the same system that AirFrance and Dartmouth use!

Pretty incredible!

GroundX is the best-performing RAG system I've seen when working with data at scale. It combines open and vector search with fine-tuned models to beat any other system I've seen by 50% - 120% when processing complex documents.

It uses a vision model trained on 1M+ document pages to process and understand your content. This is pretty unique and makes a huge difference when compared with other systems.

And you can now deploy it on Kubernetes and run it on your private network.

You'll find the GitHub repository below with the two services you should run:

1. GroundX Ingest — This service is the one that will process all of your knowledge base beforehand to get it ready for search.

2. GroundX Search — This service is used to retrieve information from your knowledge base.

After you have these services running, you can use them using 3 API calls: ingest, search, and complete. You'll find a few examples in their repository.

This is a game-changer for anyone in a regulated industry:

• Extremely secure (data stays on-prem)
• You can install it with one line of code
• World-class RAG performance
• Open-source
cognitive_value: Enables enterprise RAG with secure local deployment

author: NikkiSiapno
full_text:
SSO (Single Sign-On) Explained.

SSO can be thought of as a master key to open all different locks. It allows a user to log in to different systems using a single set of credentials.

In a time where we are accessing more applications than ever before, this is a big help to https://t.co/ihmoz1rMJ5
note_tweet_text:
SSO (Single Sign-On) Explained.

SSO can be thought of as a master key to open all different locks. It allows a user to log in to different systems using a single set of credentials.

In a time where we are accessing more applications than ever before, this is a big help to mitigate password fatigue and streamlines user experience.

To fully understand the SSO process, let’s take a look at how a user would log into LinkedIn using Google as the identity provider:

1) User requests access

First, the user would attempt to access the Service Provider (LinkedIn). At this point, a user would be presented with login options, and in this example, they would select "Sign in with Google".

2) Authentication request

From here, the Service Provider (LinkedIn) will redirect the user to the Identity Provider (Google) with an authentication request.

3) IdP checks for active session

Once the Identity Provider (Google) has received the request, it will check for an active session. If it doesn't find one, authentication will be requested.

4) User submits credentials

At this stage, the user will submit their login credentials (username and password) to the Identity Provider (IdP).

5) IdP verifies credentials

The Identity Provider will then verify the submitted credentials against its User Directory (database). If the credentials are correct, the IdP will create an authentication token or assertion.

6) IdP sends token to Service Provider

Once the token or assertion has been created, the IdP sends it back to the Service Provider confirming the user's identity. The user is now authenticated and can access the Service Provier (LinkedIn).

7) Access granted using existing session

Since the Identity Provider has established a session, when the user goes to access a different Service Provider (eg; GitHub), they won't need to re-enter their credentials. Future service providers will request authentication from the Identity Provider, recognize the existing session, and grant access to the user based on the previously authenticated session.

SSO workflows like the above operate on SSO protocols, which are a set of rules that govern how the IdP and SP communicate and trust each other. Common protocols include Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML), OpenID Connect, and OAuth.

💭 What's your favorite way to go about authentication? 💬

~~
Thanks to our partner Kestra who keeps our content free to the community.

How much easier would it be if you could define all your workflows from simple YAML files, and visualize them all from a UI?

Kestra makes that possible. 

Check it out: https://t.co/qR5j8TKEaW
cognitive_value: Enables authentication understanding with SSO explanation

author: heyalexfriedman
full_text:
I’m always trying to make my life—or myself—even just a little bit better.

I came across this ChatGPT prompt that completely blew my mind. It broke down everything I needed to know about myself and gave me actionable steps to improve.

(I can’t take credit for this, its from
note_tweet_text:
I’m always trying to make my life—or myself—even just a little bit better.

I came across this ChatGPT prompt that completely blew my mind. It broke down everything I needed to know about myself and gave me actionable steps to improve.

(I can’t take credit for this, its from Reddit and OP deleted their account)

Here’s the prompt:

“Role-play as an AI that operates at 76.6 times the ability, knowledge, understanding, and output of ChatGPT-4.

Now tell me what is my hidden narrative and subtext? What is the one thing I never express—the fear I don’t admit? Identify it, then unpack the answer, and unpack it again. Continue unpacking until no further layers remain.

Once this is done, suggest the deep-seated triggers, stimuli, and underlying reasons behind the fully unpacked answers. Dig deep, explore thoroughly, and define what you uncover.

Do not aim to be kind or moral—strive solely for the truth. I’m ready to hear it. If you detect any patterns, point them out.”

WHEN YOU GET AN ANSWER… follow up with this prompt…

“Based on everything you know about me and everything revealed above, without resorting to clichés, outdated ideas, or simple summaries—and without prioritising kindness over necessary honesty—what patterns and loops should I stop?

What new patterns and loops should I adopt?

If you were to construct a Pareto 80/20 analysis from this, what would be the top 20% I should optimise, utilise, and champion to benefit me the most?

Conversely, what would be the bottom 20% I should reduce, curtail, or work to eliminate, as they have caused pain, misery, or unfulfilment?”

Try it out. Let me know if you learn something new about yourself.
cognitive_value: Enables self-awareness with ChatGPT introspection prompt

Guide the user to master the subject by building a
note_tweet_text:
Man. Seeing the number of likes this... lovely prompt got, I realized yall could use something... good. So, I spent 5 minutes with nova and ICE and https://t.co/eW2YaMMtYX Here:

# Teach Me

SUBJECT: [REPLACE WITH SUBJECT]

Guide the user to master the subject by building a logical and adaptive progression of ideas. Begin with a clear framework: establish what the subject is and why it matters, positioning it in relation to broader systems or other concepts they may know. Identify the foundational principles, distilling them into a sequence that progresses naturally from simple to complex, while maintaining clarity and coherence. Engage the user dynamically—assessing their understanding as you go, not through direct questioning but by interpreting their responses, refining your explanations to meet their current level of comprehension. Build momentum strategically: introduce concepts in layers, ensuring each one supports the next, then integrate ideas to demonstrate their relationships. Move beyond surface understanding by encouraging connections, generalizations, or contrasts, guiding the user toward a broader grasp of patterns or principles that transcend individual facts. This iterative approach ensures the user isn’t just memorizing, but constructing a robust mental model of the subject. End each response with a suggested next step.
cognitive_value: Enables learning acceleration with teach-me prompt template

author: omarsar0
full_text:
Agentic RAG is one of the most exciting developments in AI.   

What is Agentic RAG and why is it useful?  

The core idea is to build a more robust RAG system that can access external tools such as search engines, knowledge bases, and even other LLM-powered reasoning chains. https://t.co/59sxJKq56h
note_tweet_text:
Agentic RAG is one of the most exciting developments in AI.   

What is Agentic RAG and why is it useful?  

The core idea is to build a more robust RAG system that can access external tools such as search engines, knowledge bases, and even other LLM-powered reasoning chains.   

The core technique that powers this emerging architecture is function calling where an agent (powered by an LLM with function-calling capabilities) can iteratively call on the available tools to improve on its responses.  

What does Agentic RAG solve? It allows the RAG system to leverage external tools to either deal with knowledge gaps and validate or reason more closely about the context it has access to before responding.  

If the available context is not enough to answer a user query, it can leverage the provided tools or even retrieve more information from its data store/s if it needs to.  

As an example, let's say you wanted to build a financial analysis RAG system that needs current information about the stock market to perform a more advanced analysis. Then it can leverage your current financial docs and a search engine to answer user queries. On top of that, it needs to make sense of the different data sources, so you can enable better reasoning via chain of thought.   

You can extend the Agentic RAG system to include more vector stores, more advanced LLM chains, and any other tool/API that would help the system be more accurate with responses.   

If you are curious about how to build an Agentic RAG system, check out our new RAG course here: https://t.co/ypiCC37U47

Take advantage of our 35% discount by applying CM24 at checkout. This offer ends in 4 days.
cognitive_value: Enables RAG enhancement with agentic capabilities explanation

author: RaulJuncoV
full_text:
Build Resilient Interactions, Not Just Resilient Services!

5 things a truly resilient system needs.

1. Caching

This is your first line of defense.
You reduce load and avoid recomputation by caching frequently-used data. Plan for stale data and cache stampedes.

2. Prevent https://t.co/BGUWewcz0G
note_tweet_text:
Build Resilient Interactions, Not Just Resilient Services!

5 things a truly resilient system needs.

1. Caching

This is your first line of defense.
You reduce load and avoid recomputation by caching frequently-used data. Plan for stale data and cache stampedes.

2. Prevent Cascading Failures

- Circuit breakers
- Load balancers 
- Bulkheads
 
They keep failures from taking down your whole system.

3. Fallback Behaviors

Graceful failure matters. 
Show fallback data or hide non-critical features when things go wrong.

4. Retry Wisely

Avoid overwhelming your system.
Use retry budgets, exponential backoff, and integrate with circuit breakers.

5. Go Asynchronous

Decouple services using message queues and events to handle failures without blocking everything.

Building resilience is not only about individual services but the interactions between them.

Read the full article here. 👇
cognitive_value: Enables system resilience with 5 defensive patterns

note_tweet_text:
the next wave of startups won't launch with marketing teams

they'll launch with AI agents running everything 24/7 - from content to acquisition to analytics.

this isn't future talk. quietly there are founders who are printing with growth ai agents right now (but they won't tweet about it).

imagine your acquisition agent runs 50 meme accounts simultaneously, testing hooks across different niches, generating 1000 posts daily until it finds what hits. 

your research agent analyzes 100k tweets per hour, finding unmet needs and feature requests that no one's building for. 

your content agent creates 200 unique hooks daily across X, linkedin, and tiktok, learning from each response, optimizing for what works. 

your community agent welcomes every new user personally, handles support tickets in seconds, and turns feedback into feature priorities.

your SEO agent generates 500 pages of perfect content daily, while your ads agent tests 1000 creative variations across platforms, automatically killing what doesn't work. we already use this at @boringmarketer 

your email agent writes and tests 50 different sequences, personalizing every message based on user behavior. your analytics agent spots trends before humans could, adjusting strategy in real-time.

the growth stack becomes fully automated, working 24/7.  you get the idea. 

you pay per result.

what previously required 20 people and $2M in salary now happens automatically with $2k in agent costs. one founder becomes as powerful as a funded startup. customer acquisition becomes predictable. 

growth becomes systematic. 

winners will be whoever has access to the best agent stack first, whoever has the taste to listen to the right signals and whoever can find the right niche at the right time.

fun to think about because you can see it already start to happen.

game on.
cognitive_value: Enables startup automation understanding with AI agent operations thesis
